facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 51 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court appealing from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 238 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 51 of 65. Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc,. Petition No. 238 of 1964.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: In 1957 the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur granted to Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon (appellants) a permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 to ply stage carriages on inter-regional route Jabalpur to Chhatarpur, countersigned by Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957 the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur granted to Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon-hereinafter called the appellants permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 to ply stage carriages on an inter- regional route-Jabalpur to Chhatarpur-in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the permit was companyntersigned by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa within whose jurisdiction a part of the route lay.

facts.text: The permit was renewed in 1960 for three years expiring on August 9, 1963 by Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, countersigned by Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: The permit was renewed in 1960 for a period of three years expiring on August 9, 1963 by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, and it was companynter signed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

facts.text: On June 7, 1963 the appellant applied to Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur for renewal of the permit.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1963 the appellant applied to the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur for renewal of the permit,

facts.text: By order dated December 6, 1963 Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for period ending February 9, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: and by order dated December 6, 1963 the permit was renewed for the period ending February 9, 1966.

facts.text: By application dated December 7, 1963 appellant requested Regional Transport Authority, Rewa to countersign the renewed permit.

anchor.surface_text: By its application dated December 7, 1963 the appellant requested the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa to companyntersign the permit so renewed.

facts.text: The application to Rewa was published on January 2, 1964 as required by s.57 read with s.63 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This application was published as required by s. 57 read with s. 63 3  of the Act on January 2, 1964.

facts.text: Three motor transport operators including first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia objected to countersignature on ground that application barred by limitation under s.58(2) proviso one.

anchor.surface_text: Three motor transport operators, amongst whom was the first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia, objected to the grant of companynter-signature to the permit, inter alia, on the ground that the application was barred by the law of limitation prescribed by s. 58 2  proviso one,

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority, Rewa overruled the objection and by order dated March 17, 1964 granted countersignature.

anchor.surface_text: and the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa had numberpower to grant companynter-signature of renewal after the expiry of that period. The Regional Transport Authority, Rewa overruled the objection, and by order dated March 17, 1964 granted companynter-signature of the permit.

facts.text: First respondent applied to Madhya Pradesh High Court under Articles 226 and 227 for writ quashing Rewa order dated March 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent then applied to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Arts. 226 227 of the Constitution for a writ quashing the order dated March 17, 1964 passed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court quashed the order dated March 17, 1964 holding application for countersignature renewal barred by s.58(2) and Rewa had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court an application for renewal of the permit and an application for renewal of companynter-signature must be made within the period prescribed by S. 58 2  of the Act, and the appellant having failed to apply within that period, the application of the appellant for renewal of the companynter-signature was barred and the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa had numberjurisdiction to companyntersign the permit renewed by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur. The High Court accordingly quashed the order dated March 17, 1964.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Article 133(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Behari Lal Chaurasia is the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: amongst whom was the first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia,

facts.text: An application for countersignature of the renewal was made to Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur and rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case an application for companynter-signature of renewal of the permit was made to the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, and it was rejected. It is unfortunate that the application and the reasons in support of the order of the Authority ire number on the record of the case. But it appears clear from the following recital in the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa, that the application for companyntersignature was made to the Authority at Jabalpur and it was rejected

facts.text: Truth of the recital in Rewa order about Jabalpur rejection accepted by counsel.

anchor.surface_text: Truth of this recital is accepted by companynsel at the Bar.

facts.text: Central Provinces and Berar Motor Vehicles Rules, 1940 were in operation in Jabalpur and Rewa regions at material time, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 the Central Provinces and Berar Motor Vehicles Rules, 1940 were made by the appropriate authority and it is companymon ground that those rules were at the material time in operation in the two regions--Jabalpur and Rewa--

facts.text: Supreme Court affirms High Court order quashing Rewa countersignature but for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons.

facts.text: Permit renewed by Jabalpur valid only for route between Jabalpur and point of entry into Rewa region.

anchor.surface_text: We deem it, however, necessary to make it clear that our order does number affect the validity of the permit -ranted by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, insofar as it relates to the route between Jabalpur and the point of entry of the route into the Rewa region.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur declined to countersign the permit for Rewa region under rule 63.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to companyntersign the permit in exercise of the power companyferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 48 it is provided that subject to the provisions of s. 47, a Regional Transport Authority may, on an application made to it, grant a stage carriage permit, in accordance with the application or with such modifications as it deems fit, valid for a specified route or routes or specified area.

An application for a stage carriage permit or a public carriers permit shall, it is provided by sub-s.  2 , be made number less than six weeks before the date on which it is desired that the permit shall take effect,

By sub-s.  1  of s. 58 it is provided that a stage carriage permit or a companytract carriage permit other than a temporary permit shall be effective without renewal for such period number less than three years and number more than five years,

Sub-section  2  enacts that a permit may be renewed on an application made and disposed of as if it were an application for a permit, pro- vided that the application for the renewal of a permit shall be made  a  in the case of a stage carriage permit or a public L7Sup.165-3 carriers permit, number less than sixty days before the date of its expiry

IV relating to grant. revocation and suspension of permits are made applicable to grant of countersignatures of permits, and to the application for countersignature of an inter- regional permit the provisions relating to renewal contained in s. 58 have numberapplication.

issues.text: Whether a permit granted by one RTA is wholly ineffective until countersigned by the other RTA for inter-regional route

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent submitted that a permit granted by an Authority competent under s. 45 of the Act is an integrated permit in respect of a unitary route, and until the permit is countersigned by the Authority in the other region, it is wholly ineffective.

arguments.claim: One RTA not competent to sit in judgment over discretion of another RTA; Rewa order granting countersignature overriding Jabalpur invalid

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is not competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statute, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

arguments.claim: Inter-regional permit valid in granting RTA's region even without countersignature by other RTA

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Renewal by Jabalpur without countersignature makes it effectively a regional permit limited to Jabalpur region; no scope for Rewa to extend by countersigning

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion is inevitable that the Authority granted the permit only operative between Jabalpur and the point at which the route entered the Rewa region in substance, he merely granted a regional permit limited to the route within the Jabalpur region.

holdings.text: Rule 63 must therefore prevail over the direction of the statute.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63 must therefore prevail over the direction of the statute. There is nosubstance in the contention raised by counsel for the appellant that the State Government had nopower to frame rule 63. Power to frame rules for carrying into effect the provisions of Ch. IV is expressly granted to the State Government by s. 68,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 63(1) begins with 'Except as may be otherwise prescribed,' making it subject to rules under s.68; Rule 63 modifies the statutory direction by empowering the issuing authority to countersign.

holdings.text: There is nosubstance in the contention raised by counsel for the appellant that the State Government had nopower to frame rule 63.

anchor.surface_text: There is nosubstance in the contention raised by counsel for the appellant that the State Government had nopower to frame rule 63. Power to frame rules for carrying into effect the provisions of Ch. IV is expressly granted to the State Government by s. 68, and the exercise of that power, if it be utilised for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Act, is not subject to any other implied limitations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68 expressly grants power to frame rules for Ch.IV; no implied limitations if used to carry out Act's provisions.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur was therefore competent to grant renewal of the permit and was also competent by virtue of rule 63 to countersign the permit so as to make it valid even for that part of the route which lay in the Rewa region.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur was therefore competent to grant renewal of the permit and was also competent by virtue of rule 63 to countersign the permit so as to make it valid even for that part of the route which lay in the Rewa region. The Legislature has by providing in the opening part of sub- s.  1  Except as may be otherwise prescribed made the pro- vision subject to the rules framed under s. 68,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 63(a) empowers renewing authority to renew countersignature unless countersigning authority directs otherwise; prevails over s.63 due to 'except as otherwise prescribed'.

holdings.text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual implication of s.63: invalid only outside granting region, hence valid within it without countersignature.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to countersign the permit in exercise of the power conferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court accepts recital in Rewa order and counsel admission that Jabalpur application made and rejected under r.63.

holdings.text: The conclusion is inevitable that the Authority granted the permit only operative between Jabalpur and the point at which the route entered the Rewa region in substance, he merely granted a regional permit limited to the route within the Jabalpur region.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since Jabalpur exercised r.63 power to decline countersigning Rewa portion, renewal limited to Jabalpur region only.

holdings.text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is not competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statute, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RTAs independent; no power to review another's discretion under statute or rules.

edges.explanation: The holding states that under S.63 a permit granted by one RTA is not valid in another region unless countersigned, directly addressing the issue of whether such a permit is wholly ineffective until countersigned for inter-regional routes.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction,

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is not competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statute, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.
